full_text: To successfully recruit diverse talent, leaders must be clear on why this is important. I authentically believe I get a better team, products & ideas. Your reasoning can be different, but it must exist to make this type of hiring successful & authentic to your company’s core. https://t.co/IkfvM43wrT

In 2019 I spoke at #CES about what comes next in technology. At the time, that included the future of deep data, AI and quantum, and preparing society for this new tech era. 

In 3 more years, what technology do you predict will be critical for society and our businesses? https://t.co/q2ePWvkwjE

A partnership should benefit both sides. For founders considering partnerships, think about what a partner wants out of the relationship. When at @IBM, we carefully crafted partnerships to build belief and test how the market would react before actually acquiring a company. https://t.co/CtY9qrt0Ls
RT @OneTen: Co-chairs Ken Frazier and @GinniRometty say it best: after an incredible year of progress, this is only the beginning for OneTe…

@HarvardBiz Black and female talent is more scarce in AI than it is in the tech industry as a whole. If we want to improve our workforces, it will be critical to look for and develop talent in new and underserved communities.

@byHeatherLong The past 2 years have been incredibly challenging for workers. Across all sectors, skills-first training will be critical for both workers and businesses to create new economic opportunities moving forward.

Successful founders should work with partners, teams and board members who can supplement their weaknesses.

As the @Enginexyz’s Visiting Innovation Fellow at @MIT, I shared advice with the next generation of leaders and founders, and now with all of you. https://t.co/3oxUvIfjID

@HarvardBiz Leaving a new job is challenging, especially in a pandemic. The Great Resignation has caused many employees to reconsider their roles and career goals. For those thinking about the risk, I recently shared my advice: https://t.co/EWpD73tCCM

I'm proud to be co-chair of @oneten and break down barriers keeping Black talent on the sidelines. In just a year we’ve made strides toward equitable change across dozens of industries and it’s only the beginning. Learn more about our progress in 2021: https://t.co/YxefZsSpHN https://t.co/YNtQVNhdvT

@CISAJen You’re right - cyber and ransomware attacks are on the rise, and people need to know how to protect themselves and their workplaces. That’s why I recently wrote about 3 basic security steps to keep in mind: https://t.co/TMTQ68IMzk

Congratulations to those recognized on the 2022 @Forbes #30Under30 Enterprise Technology List. As leaders, I encourage you to be responsible tech stewards and foster inclusive workplaces — both are critical for society and your organization’s success. https://t.co/Iuu6MjO3GN

@profwolff COVID-19 caused millions of workers to re-evaluate their personal and career goals. Moving forward, it will be critical for businesses to collaborate with their employees on new ways of working. I recently shared this and other pandemic lessons: https://t.co/2R1MXUfm3R
@ChuckDBrooks Cyberattacks are on the rise, especially with hybrid workforces. I recently shared the basic, yet critical steps we can take to protect our organizations: https://t.co/TMTQ68IMzk

@joemckendrick This is both a challenge and a great opportunity. In the midst of the #GreatResignation, organizations are challenged to expand their search for recruits, which presents an incredible opportunity to hire more diverse talent.

@PostLive @morningmika COVID-19 showed us that what works for one employee may not for another. Leaders must collaborate with their teams to find the best ways to work — whether remote, in person, or a mix of both. I recently shared this, and more lessons from the pandemic: https://t.co/2R1MXUfm3R

Taking on a new job is always a challenge, but even more so during a pandemic. For those of you who’ve changed jobs since the pandemic began, what have you learned that’s important for others to think about? https://t.co/kvHTvf5P9x

The impacts of the pandemic and non-inclusive workplaces are exacerbating the #GreatResignation. We have an opportunity to make our businesses better now and for the long term by recruiting diverse talent and fostering an inclusive culture. https://t.co/vtojnDz2Iy
@OneTen @GuildEducation Welcome to the team, @GuildEducation. We’re looking forward to working together to train and hire one million Black Americans over the next 10 years together.
@IndraNooyi I could not agree more, Indra. I always say, diversity is a number and inclusion is a choice.

I was one of the only women in my engineering classes at @NorthwesternU. Today women earn 53% of STEM degrees. Thank you @IBM, for supporting STEM education at @NorthwesternEng — A place that made my career, and the careers of many other women, possible. https://t.co/SLTgDLO0iJ

@NUAlumni @IBM @NorthwesternEng I am so grateful for @IBM’s generous gift — @NorthwesternU and @NorthwesternEng were critical in shaping my passion for education and technology, and for my career at IBM.

With many people changing jobs during the #GreatResignation, I shared some of the lessons learned during my 40-year career @IBM.

Now I want to know: what other career advice can you share for people thinking about changing jobs? https://t.co/H6QEBGreAU

@guardian The pandemic caused many workers to reconsider their priorities and goals, and many people are unsure of what’s next. For those considering a change, I shared the advice I learned from my own career at @IBM: https://t.co/EWpD73tCCM

@avrohomg @NETSCOUT @TylerCohenWood @ChuckDBrooks @EvanKirstel @AkwyZ Prioritizing data protection and cyber security is critical to keep our organizations safe. With cyber attacks on the rise, I also shared steps to prevent and recover from attacks: https://t.co/TMTQ68IMzk

The past two years have been eye-opening for millions of workers — many have reevaluated their priorities and career goals. As we face a #GreatResignation, I’ve decided to share the advice I learned in my career to help those struggling with what’s next. https://t.co/ljRFCYOifS
@TRIResearch_ @SiennaEthics With new technology comes the responsibility to understand and prepare for all of its uses — the good and the bad.

It was a pleasure to join @_SueSiegel and @Enginexyz’s Tough Tech Summit and share the lessons I learned in my career with young entrepreneurs. An authentic belief in diversity and inclusion will make you a better company. https://t.co/s7YLgy7srG

@TechNative @corixpartners Hybrid work environments have blurred the lines between home and work, and can lead to increased vulnerability to cyber attacks. I shared my tips for preventing and recovering from attacks in a recent article: https://t.co/TMTQ68IMzk

@ciscoapac @kerrymsingleton With cyber and ransomware attacks on the rise, companies must not lose sight of security basics. Thanks for sharing your tips — I shared a few of mine in a recent article: https://t.co/TMTQ68IMzk

@CTVAtlantic I am thrilled to see @PTECHNETWORK and @IBMCanada supporting Indigenous students. This relationship will be good for these students, their communities, and the businesses who will benefit from their perspectives.

@gcluley Because data and privacy are more important than ever, it is critical for organizations to prepare their networks for cyber and ransomware attacks. I recently wrote about the basic steps every organization can take: https://t.co/TMTQ68IMzk

At @IBM, I learned that skills and a desire to learn were far more important for success than a college degree. Removing barriers to enter the workforce will create more economic opportunities, while also making our businesses better. https://t.co/lNfAZllskX

@EdWeekEdTech @Larryferlazzo Digital technology became critical to education during COVID-19. It must continue to be accessible and part of our education system to not deepen the digital divide in the years to come.
@byHeatherLong As we continue to learn from the impacts of COVID-19, now is the time to make changes that better support our employees and their families. https://t.co/O7lSK28Q4y

@WhiteHouseCEA While the economy and workforce are recovering from COVID-19, the September #JobsReport shows businesses are struggling to bring back workers. The pandemic made clear our workplaces need to change. Businesses must cocreate with their employees to find the right solutions.

We know the pandemic has disproportionately impacted women, and specifically women of color, in the workforce. As employers, we need to consider how we can better support women throughout their careers because they are critical for our economy. https://t.co/b6AexBB0L0

@DrTarikaBarrett @GirlsWhoCode @CISAgov This is great news, @DrTarikaBarrett! Non-traditional career pathways are critical in creating a more diverse workforce, particularly for cybersecurity and #WomeninSTEM. — Here I wrote about how we integrate recruits without traditional 4-year degrees: https://t.co/ki9AR2omAP
@liseeng @IBM I’m so happy these lessons resonated with you. My time at @IBM was invaluable, and it taught me when challenges arise we must act. The pandemic has been the ultimate challenge.

@IndraNooyi @davepuente Thank YOU, Indra, for sharing your story of #MyLifeInFull. And congratulations on your book. I can’t wait to read about the many challenges you’ve had to overcome — in your life & your career — and to see what comes next for one of the most impressive & accomplished women I know.
@sloan_kettering Thank you #MSKHealthcareHeroes for being important role models. It’s so important to uplift doctors to show young women and girls where careers in #STEM can lead.
If it’s a problem that can’t be fixed, then you should move on. But you still want to make sure that your next job is one you’re excited and passionate about.

Or are you running FROM a bad work environment? Do you feel frustrated by a bad boss, a tough schedule, or just feel stuck in place? At a good company, these issues are often temporary, and may be resolved if you pause and try to address the issue.

People often ask for my advice when they’re thinking about changing jobs. My response is always to ask them the same question: Are you running TO a new opportunity that really excites you? If so, that’s great. #GreatResignation https://t.co/rzeFzmGfgI

@USDOL @BLS_gov Diversity is a number; inclusion is a choice. Integrating workers of different backgrounds must be done with an authentic belief that it will make you a better company - because it will. #HispanicHeritageMonth
My friend @mtbarra is an agent of change. Her power lies in empowering others. She urges women to go for it. I can think of no one more deserving of the honor of #TIME100. https://t.co/iFqkX40s00

The idea of spending nearly 40 years at one company is probably unthinkable for many workers today. My advice from a career @IBM is to do what you love and work with a company whose purpose aligns with your own. https://t.co/LAiETlwrQe

School is about more than just learning for learning’s sake; it’s an opportunity to learn how to solve problems. No matter what you do in life or what career you choose, problem solving will be the core of your work. #BackToSchool https://t.co/ZvaZF3jO6y

@NorthwesternU I’m so proud to see my alma mater taking on this challenge. To create a more diverse and successful industry, we need to change paradigms to make careers in STEM accessible to people of all backgrounds.

The talents of too many Black Americans are being wasted because they are denied equal opportunities to succeed. I’m proud to work with @MauriceOneTen and our @OneTen coalition to promote family-sustaining careers for Black individuals. https://t.co/n0Np2cChvi

@dnbglobal #Cybersecurity analysts are a great example of where companies can strengthen and diversify their workforce through skills-based hiring. I wrote about what we learned at #IBM and how others can apply those lessons. https://t.co/ki9AR2omAP

Opportunity can be an equalizer. As we remember the March on Washington, I’m proud that the @OneTen coalition is continuing the fight for equality by creating economic opportunity and meaningful jobs for Black Americans. https://t.co/V7luvuAtLs

@axios I’m glad to see this administration and industry leaders taking cybersecurity and ransomware threats seriously. But also remember security and data protection for most people and organizations starts with basic precautions. https://t.co/TMTQ68IMzk

Companies need to constantly raise the bar on taking preemptive action to address cybersecurity. Organizational actions to keep systems and data secure can be complex - but it’s important for all of us not to forget the basics. https://t.co/01sPgBRnpk

Organizations should expect sophisticated attacks and proactively prepare for recovery. If you get the flu, the goal is to stop it from turning into pneumonia. If you suffer an attack, you want to stop it from spreading and infecting your entire network. https://t.co/ZRgQufAvsP
@briankrebs I recently wrote about a few of the basic strategies organizations can use to stop attacks like this before they impact the entire network: https://t.co/TMTQ690nqS

@gcluley We expect cyber breaches to come from sophisticated attacks, but they often come from simple mistakes. In my recent article, I wrote about how essential basic precautions are, and how they’re often forgotten when we blur the lines between home and office: https://t.co/TMTQ690nqS
Cybersecurity is a priority at every level. As attacks become more advanced, the next generation of leaders, like the Girl Scouts, will need to be prepared. Great work! https://t.co/qfryTGVktz
RT @GirlsWhoCode: "I learned to always take on things I'd never done before. Growth and comfort do not coexist." - @GinniRometty, the first…

Applying AI to cybersecurity will present organizations with the opportunity to spot the early warning signs of bad actors by identifying patterns that are too complex for humans alone. You must fight tech with tech. https://t.co/njjI82dRU3

Cybersecurity attacks can be sophisticated, but it is often simple mistakes that open the door. It’s important to constantly review security basics and access permissions, especially for those in hybrid work environments. https://t.co/Alyb23qCnE

STEM is the launch pad that provides students the skills they need to solve problems with technology solutions. #InternationalYouthDay reminds us that we need young people to create technologically-driven global change to solve our world’s most pressing health problems. https://t.co/UOYOeKNhM1
@NextCityOrg Together we have the opportunity to create a more equitable work force. Thanks, @NextCityOrg for your commitment.

The key to cybersecurity is to be proactive. My next Lessons Learned series shares steps to protect organizations from cyberattacks:
1. Keep revisiting the basics
2. Accelerate the use of AI in Cybersecurity
3. Put your effort into recovery and resilience
https://t.co/TRKb60Ls99
Gabby Thomas is a role model for young girls in the classroom and on the track. Congratulations, @ItsGabrielleT! https://t.co/8xOfyqSaw7

While we’ve been looking forward to reopening for over a year, the challenges of the pandemic will not disappear. They will persist, but with the opportunity to create enduring change that will make our businesses and communities better. What have you learned about leadership? https://t.co/vZSGTtdHbY
@DrTarikaBarrett Thank you for sharing Jocelyn’s story. Jocelyn is another great example of the many women in STEM who overcame significant challenges and made historic contributions.

@OneTen The best way to drive enduring change in your companies is to co-create with employees — people are more receptive to change when they’re part of the conversation. When you lead with employees’ best interests in mind, they’ll feel that. https://t.co/6B1m7EIWyw

The pandemic disproportionately affected communities of color. That’s why I helped launch @OneTen, an organization that will bring together businesses and talent providers to create one million jobs for Black Americans over the next 10 years. https://t.co/GOuqJlEPSh

Women offer a valuable perspective on COVID-19 recovery — they’ve lost jobs at a faster rate than men and bore the brunt of childcare. We know women are good for business, but to make a difference in an organization they must also be included in decision making conversations. https://t.co/ICD7u0OOzN

Authenticity and transparency have become more important than ever before for businesses to build trust. This trust is essential for workers to feel valued, for investors to feel secure, and for consumers to believe companies are doing the right thing. https://t.co/T19TbXMBvI

It’s been 52 years since man first landed on the moon. Slowly over that time, we’ve begun to honor the Black women who made that feat a possibility: Mary Jackson, Katherine Johnson, and Dorothy Vaughan. https://t.co/oxH6ZCzMB3

@2Uinc @OneTen Together we can bring 1 million Black Americans into the workforce over the next 10 years. With the help of talent developers like @2Uinc, we can prepare individuals for long-term, family sustaining jobs.

The COVID-19 pandemic exposed many challenges and opportunities for business leaders, and has given us an opportunity to come back better than before. These lessons can help workplaces change to better suit their employees and customers: https://t.co/FWQT0mwaa2

Thank you, @SvonFriedeburg. Diversity is a fact but inclusion is a choice we make. I was proud to be part of this conversation, sharing what’s worked and what hasn’t, so we can collectively make tech a better and more inclusive industry. https://t.co/rP0TYvRoOu

@postlive @sbp04 The pandemic showed us how fragile equality is, and the tech industry has an opportunity to create a more inclusive work force. It was a pleasure to talk about how we can bring this vision to life, @postlive and @sbp04.

Going into STEM is a launch pad, not a destination, that will provide women with the skills to be problem solvers wherever their career leads. Thank you, @postlive for inviting me to talk about the importance of technology education with Ruth Porat, @sbp04 and @byHeatherLong. https://t.co/eL6gzgDMvq

During #Pride month, we’re reminded how important it is to live freely and authentically. That’s why when I was CEO at @IBM I wanted employees to feel safe, supported and accepted - so everyone could be their best selves, no matter who they are. https://t.co/Vzg8m545yr

Over the past year, countless commitments were made to support Black Americans, but now we must execute on the promises. #Juneteenth is a day to commemorate emancipation, while also looking forward to the significant work that remains to make America an equitable place. https://t.co/s6dMD4oV9B

@IBM The incredible people and clients I worked with, and IBM’s commitment to being leaders in good tech were the best parts of my 40 year career. I know IBM will continue to be an inspiring and world-changing place over the next 110 years.

Advancements, like new technologies, come with huge opportunities for our society - and critical responsibilities to one another. 

Graduates, remember: to be successful in life and business, as you focus on the "wins," be sure they benefit the many not just the few. https://t.co/RxIDh2q3tn
@techreview The purpose of AI is to make humans better. When we adapt it we can grow the skills of our employees and help them do more.

If you want diversity and inclusion efforts to be successful, you must genuinely believe it will make your company better. @techreview, it was a pleasure to join you to talk about @OneTen and the future of technology. https://t.co/WqyW7xfvyx

I recently sat down with @mtbarra, chairman and CEO of @GM, for the first conversation in my 3-in-3 series. I’ve compiled Mary’s insights and lessons about leadership, including an extra chat on speed and empowerment, to share with you here. https://t.co/263fg9mx1Q

@DrTarikaBarrett It is so important that girls see themselves in these industries. After all, you can’t be what you can’t see. @GirlsWhoCode is a key player in making sure girls develop these valuable skills and see themselves in the world of STEM careers. Plus, companies can’t wait to hire them!

@pattiesellers @kayelbee @_emmahinchliffe @FortuneMagazine Was it Jill Barad, CEO of @Mattel? 

Congratulations on 23 years of acknowledging women’s achievements in business and inspiring many more to follow in their footsteps.

Now that I’ve shared my tips for building an inclusive workplace culture, I want to hear yours. What has your experience been, either as an employer or employee? What challenges have you faced and how did you overcome them? https://t.co/OpuCdXHzFW
@Allstate @MauriceOneTen @OneTen Thank you for joining @OneTen. Your commitment to upskilling, hiring and advancing Black individuals is an important element in pursuit of racial equity.
@ChuckRobbins @Cisco Thank you @ChuckRobbins and @Cisco for joining @OneTen. I am grateful for your partnership as we work to create 1 million family sustaining jobs for Black Americans.

During my last years at IBM, 15% of our U.S. hires were new collar hires. For this to work, we must hire in peer groups because it’s important to help people see themselves in a position where they can thrive with the right support. https://t.co/45is96E5TR

One of the most important things you can do as CEO is ensure new hires without traditional 4-year degrees are integrated into the company as full-fledged members of the team. CEOs can inspire a top-down approach and make training a high priority within the company's culture. https://t.co/fBNHjyKU6d

Apprenticeships are an alternative career pathway that allow new hires the ability to earn while they learn. These opportunities are critical in bringing into the workforce those who need to support themselves or their family while they build new in demand skills. https://t.co/ouaBlSqjmb

Good managers are critical to new hires’ growth, especially hires without traditional four-year degrees. As we shift from a paradigm in which you “buy” skills to one in which you “build” skills, managers become even more important for training and retaining talent. https://t.co/IRfbDXOOtF

While I was at @IBM, our top hiring criteria became a candidate’s propensity to learn (vs their degree) - It’s most telling of how they will perform on the job.

An aptitude-based hiring approach will make our businesses better and make new hires more likely to succeed and grow. https://t.co/vL5e3dJIeT

When integrating workers without four-year degrees into your workforce, it makes sense to start with the job families in your company that are growing. Many jobs inside and outside of tech don't require college degrees to start, rather we can teach the skills for the job. https://t.co/ElxdIVkJHO

Requiring a 4-year degree can limit your talent pool and is a systemic barrier to economic opportunity. Hiring for skills instead of degrees is good for society and for your business - if you do it right.

My 6 lessons for how you can integrate recruits: https://t.co/ki9AR2omAP

Today @MikeBloomberg announced the fourth annual Bloomberg New Economy Forum in Singapore this November 16-19. I'm looking forward to joining fellow leaders as we build a path towards a more inclusive global economy. #NewEconForum https://t.co/6tkhpp3IO0
@yara @IBM It was great to join @stholsether today. It is so important that we all do work that matters. @yara is certainly doing just that.
@IBM For over 50 years IBM has made climate a priority. Looking forward to seeing the transition to zero greenhouse gas emissions.

Dr. @kkariko’s story of resilience proves why you should never give up on yourself. 
 
She studied mRNA with an unconventional approach - and struggled throughout her career in academia. Now her research has the potential to change healthcare. https://t.co/253v4QgVd5

@GM @mtbarra As @mtbarra said, laying the foundation internally is essential for pivoting an organization – just as @GM is doing in its commitment to make electric vehicles an option for everyone. I'm so grateful Mary took the time to share her insights about this leadership inflection point.
@Benioff @mtbarra Thanks for sharing, Marc. I’m so happy you enjoyed this series as much as @mtbarra and I enjoyed filming it.

Thank you, @mtbarra for helping me launch my 3-in-3 video series - 3 topics in 3 minutes each. We covered leadership lessons, how Mary is pivoting @GM, and the importance of balance. Watch the full series here, and tell me who you’d like to hear from next: https://t.co/xShnLkBwz0 https://t.co/jzxGzBuNb4
@DrTarikaBarrett @GirlsWhoCode @reshmasaujani Congratulations on taking the next step in your leadership at @GirlsWhoCode, Tarika. The work you have done and will continue to do matters deeply.

My friend @mtbarra helped launch my 3-in-3 series – 3 conversations, each three minutes long where we cover lessons in leadership and business. In our second conversation Mary and I talked all about @GM. Watch here: https://t.co/2Y384yMon3 https://t.co/sUTQhytqKb
By training our workers for the jobs of the future, we can build a stronger and more resilient New York. This initiative will make our workforce more inclusive. https://t.co/Q9F4Glasaz

Today I am sharing my third conversation with @mtbarra — all about how her family has influenced her career at @GM and the advice - good and bad - she received along the way. Watch our third 3-in-3 conversation here: https://t.co/iRyW73eCCT https://t.co/tu9HPT0ktJ

@WomenInTechShow I’ll start - Dr. Shirley Jackson began her career as one of just two Black women @MIT undergrads, then served at @The_ONR, and now is the President of @rpi. Shirley reminds me - you are a role model in everything you do - whether that is your goal or not.

Educating students through experiences - not just simulations - lets us shift to a skills-first paradigm. @PTECHNETWORK is an example of how skills-based learning can empower underserved students and create a pipeline for talent that employers need. https://t.co/fmuEfS0lEZ

3-in-3 is back, and in just 3 minutes, @mtbarra and I are talking all about @GM, including what it means to earn customer trust, and how she plans to bring electric vehicles to the mass market. Watch our conversation here: https://t.co/2Y384yMon3 https://t.co/fAuxOp8ifN

@Citi Being first can be lonely. We have to support one another.

Diana embodies what it means to define your own story. @FromCaliToMars is proof that when you have the opportunity to contribute your skills, the sky - or should I say, Mars - is the limit. https://t.co/QniAXUD5Ej

@iamwill Time is of the essence - We all need to shift to a "skills-first" paradigm for education and hiring now.

Congratulations, @Thasunda Brown Duckett! After transforming @Chase both physically and digitally, there is no better choice to lead @TIAA through the economic challenges and transformations ahead. https://t.co/NpCbh8tP5r

On @Oprah’s Master Class podcast, Dr. @CondoleezzaRice shares how her story came together to make her wiser and prepared her for making the hard decisions as the first Black woman Secretary of State and now as director of @HooverInst. https://t.co/hXtTNT02xL https://t.co/ayHVTxoovn
@thedotank Bobbi, you describe Arne so well, he remains an inspiration to so many – including me. My deepest sympathies are with your family during this time.
@workofthefuture @IBM I’m looking forward to joining the @MIT community to talk about new collar jobs, skills for the digital era, and more.

At 14, @_TheAbstract1 hacked @PathwaysInTech’s computer system. Rather than punish him, @RashidfDavis helped hone his skills. In 2015, Gabriel graduated with an associate degree and now works for @IBM. How are you recognizing and fostering untapped talent? https://t.co/V8E0tArMsj

I will be forever grateful for having had such a dear friend & role model in Arne Sorenson. Leaning on one another & learning from each other over the years has been invaluable. This week, @BENS_org’s report examining America’s collective crisis response capabilities concluded that significant execution challenges remain. In @FortuneMagazine, I explain why technology & education are essential to prepare for the next crisis: https://t.co/Qt2yEokluu

18% of students graduate with a STEM degree, only 2% are Black. @KizzyPhD led COVID-19 vaccine development & is a role model for women & people of color in STEM. Whether it’s a woman or any group, people have got to have role models to see what’s possible.
https://t.co/h0fSLIdmzh

I am one of many saluting Ken Frazier as he announces his retirement from @Merck.

I count myself lucky - I had the opportunity to learn from him as a peer, & now we are working together to co-chair @OneTen. 1M jobs for Black Americans are in our reach. 
https://t.co/9qJ9Tqph8e

I’m curious about what you’re interested in. As I begin my next chapter, what content would you like to see?

Resolving intergenerational inequity of Black Americans can’t be achieved with words and sentiments. As co-chair of @OneTen, I’m looking forward to working with fellow executives to build new talent pipelines towards family-sustaining jobs. https://t.co/tz54PocVjl

The @IBM values and purpose instilled in me nearly 40 years ago are just as relevant today. They are part of me. As 2021 challenges us in new ways, remember that each of us shape the communities we live and work in just as much as they shape us.

My experiences at @IBM have shaped who I am today and how I see the world. Meanwhile, our work at IBM has shaped the world around us. I know that IBM will continue that journey of progress and growth ever onward. https://t.co/1d18m7qtdD

My third and final lesson from my time at @IBM, work on something that matters. My belief in the power of diversity has grown into a calling to build an inclusive workforce. Diversity is a fact, but inclusion is a choice we make. https://t.co/Tji0dUVHoY

After nearly 40 years at @IBM, I’m sharing my lessons for IBMers with all of you. My first, never let anyone else define you. You write your own story. https://t.co/goalPJSonU
@PTECHNETWORK It has been an honor and joy to support P-TECH’s critical work. Together, we are preparing students with skills for the Digital Era.

@rashidfdavis @IBMorg @IBM @IBMNews Thank you, Rashid. I am so grateful for our work together. Your dedication to skills-based education is invaluable. I’m proud to see P-TECH students become tomorrow’s leaders.

I know that under @ArvindKrishna’s leadership, you will carry @IBM ever onward. It has been the honor and privilege of a lifetime to work with you IBMers, I look forward to watching as you carry this great company into the future. https://t.co/tFyogdxv0Q

There are innumerable lessons but three stand out to me:
1. Never let anyone else define you.
2. Growth and comfort never coexist.
3. Work on something that matters.

Almost 40 years ago, I came to @IBM determined to make an impact on the world. As I step down from my role as executive chairman, I know that IBM will still be part of my next chapter — it will live on in the values and purpose it has instilled in me.
